content: How can I help you today?

I guess I’ve been struggling to figure things out at home. My son has been having some serious behavioral issues, and my wife and I are at odds about how to address it. It feels like everything’s falling apart, and I’m just… stuck in it all.

That sounds like such a heavy and overwhelming situation to face. It must be really tough to feel stuck in the middle of it all, especially when it involves your son and your relationship with your wife. What’s this been like for you day to day?

Honestly, it's exhausting. I can’t focus at work, and I just don’t feel like doing much of anything anymore. It’s like everything revolves around trying to manage my son’s behavior, and it’s pulling me away from my wife and even my daughter. Nothing feels enjoyable right now.

It sounds like you’re carrying so much right now—between work, parenting, and managing the tension at home, it’s understandable that you’re feeling drained and disconnected. You’re trying to hold everything together, but it doesn’t leave much space for you or the things you usually enjoy. How do you feel about the way all of this has been affecting you?
It’s been weighing on me a lot. I feel like I’m failing everyone—my son, my wife, my daughter, even myself. I just don’t know how to get out of this cycle, and it makes me feel so stuck and hopeless.

That sense of feeling stuck and like you’re letting everyone down sounds so painful—and it’s clear how much you care about your family and want to make things better. It takes a lot of strength to open up about how hard this has been for you. What does “getting out of this cycle” look like to you, if you could imagine it?

I guess it would mean being able to help my son so he’s in a better place, and my wife and I wouldn’t constantly be at odds. I’d feel like I had energy again—to enjoy being with my family, to focus at work, to not feel like everything’s falling apart all the time. But it just feels so far away, like I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like you really long for more peace at home, more connection with your family, and to feel like yourself again. Even though it feels far away right now, the fact that you’re thinking about what you want tells me how deeply you care and that change matters to you. What do you think might be one small step toward getting closer to that place?

I'm not sure where to begin, honestly. Maybe talking to you is a small first step. I just… I don’t know what could actually make a difference right now, or what’s even worth trying. It all feels so overwhelming.

Starting this conversation truly is a meaningful first step, and recognizing how overwhelmed you feel shows your willingness to work through this, even though it’s tough. When everything feels this daunting, sometimes taking one manageable step can help bring a little clarity. What’s one area—maybe your son, your relationship with your wife, or even caring for yourself—that feels most important to focus on at this moment?

I guess if I had to pick, it would be my son. He's the one the whole family seems to be struggling around right now, and it’s really hard not knowing how to help him or get him to a place where things feel more stable. I feel like if we could figure that part out, maybe everything else would start to fall into place. But I just don’t know how.

Your love and concern for your son really shine through. It makes sense that focusing on him feels like it could be the key to helping the whole family feel more at ease and connected. Even though you’re not sure how to move forward yet, the fact that you’re so committed to helping him is a powerful foundation. If you think about your son and what he might need most, what comes to mind?

I think he needs support, more than anything. But I don’t know how to give him what he needs in a way that actually helps. My wife and I don’t agree on how to handle things, which just makes it harder. Maybe he needs someone outside the family to help, like a counselor or something, but even that feels like a big step. I don’t know if it would even help.

It sounds like you’re really tuned in to your son’s need for support, and that shows how much you want to be there for him. It also sounds like the disagreements with your wife and the uncertainty about what would help have added to the weight you’re carrying. Thinking about bringing in outside support, like a counselor, feels like a significant idea—it’s understandable for it to feel like a big step. What would it take for you to feel more confident about exploring that option?

It’s just hard to know if a counselor could actually make a difference, and I’m not sure how my son would even feel about it. I guess if I saw it helping him and making things easier at home, it might feel worth it. But taking that first step feels overwhelming, like where do you even start?

Not knowing where to start can feel really overwhelming, especially when you’re hoping for a real, meaningful change. It makes sense that you’d want to know it could truly help before taking that step. Even if it doesn’t feel clear right now, recognizing this possibility is a start. What do you think might help you feel less stuck in figuring out what that first step could look like?

Maybe I could talk to my wife about it and see how she feels about looking for a counselor for our son. I know we don’t always agree, but if it’s for him, it could be worth trying to get on the same page. Starting small like that feels a little less overwhelming.

Talking with your wife to explore counseling for your son feels like a thoughtful and proactive step, especially since it gives you both a chance to align your efforts for his benefit. Even though it might not be an easy conversation, it shows your dedication to supporting him and working as a team. How do you feel about giving that a try?

It’s worth a try, I think. I’ll bring it up with her and see where the conversation goes. It at least feels like something I can do instead of just feeling stuck. Thanks for helping me think through all of this—it’s still overwhelming, but a little less hopeless right now.
